commit_message:
Update TOX/UPPER_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/ussuri

Update the URL to the upper-constraints file to point to the redirect
rule on releases.openstack.org so that anyone working on this branch
will switch to the correct upper-constraints list automatically when
the requirements repository branches.

Until the requirements repository has as stable/ussuri branch, tests will
continue to use the upper-constraints list on master.

Change-Id: I415c2d6e558bab07227b241587782d0431c8e01d

subject: [ussuri][goal] Drop python 2.7 support and testing
messages: [{'account_id': 6547, 'date': '2020-06-09 14:32:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Cherry Picked from branch master.'}, {'account_id': 7973, 'date': '2020-06-09 15:29:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 27954, 'date': '2020-06-09 15:30:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2020-06-09 14:32:40.000000000', 'message': '[ussuri][goal] Drop python 2.7 support and testing

OpenStack is dropping the py2.7 support in ussuri cycle.

python-barbicanclient is ready with python 3 and ok to drop the
python 2.7 support.

Complete discussion & schedule can be found in
- http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-October/010142.html
- https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/drop-python2-support

Ussuri Communtiy-wide goal:
https://governance.openstack.org/tc/goals/selected/ussuri/drop-py27.html

Change-Id: Id55914141099650752027aa9dc0ad8a90528a2e9
(cherry picked from commit 69a14917e5f98f82dd1f4cdf33a49e6f3f708c13)
'}]
commit_message:
[ussuri][goal] Drop python 2.7 support and testing

OpenStack is dropping the py2.7 support in ussuri cycle.

python-barbicanclient is ready with python 3 and ok to drop the
python 2.7 support.

Complete discussion & schedule can be found in
- http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-October/010142.html
- https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/drop-python2-support

Ussuri Communtiy-wide goal:
https://governance.openstack.org/tc/goals/selected/ussuri/drop-py27.html

Change-Id: Id55914141099650752027aa9dc0ad8a90528a2e9
(cherry picked from commit 69a14917e5f98f82dd1f4cdf33a49e6f3f708c13)

subject: Correctly fetch upper constraints from opendev.org
messages:
[{'account_id': 27838, 'date': '2019-04-25 12:42:35.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2019-05-04 15:57:36.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1

I've proposed an alternative [1] which simply removes tox_install.sh. I'm going to wait and see what people think of that and if it gets shot down, I'm happy to go with this :)

[1] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/657124/"}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2019-05-06 20:34:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

Let's fix the way we're accessing constraints and drop tox_install.sh."}, {'account_id': 2, 'date': '2020-06-09 15:40:46.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-04-25 12:42:35.000000000', 'message': 'Correctly fetch upper constraints from opendev.org

tox_install.sh uses curl w/o -L switch so it fails to account for
redirects that are now in place for backward compat with
git.openstack.org.

-L option added allowing curl to redirect

Change-Id: I05552c957ee6ca2dab73d4e79366c8979392eba0
'}]
commit_message:
Correctly fetch upper constraints from opendev.org

tox_install.sh uses curl w/o -L switch so it fails to account for
redirects that are now in place for backward compat with
git.openstack.org.

-L option added allowing curl to redirect

Change-Id: I05552c957ee6ca2dab73d4e79366c8979392eba0

commit_message:
Switch to stestr

According to Openstack summit session [1],
stestr is maintained project to which all Openstack projects should migrate.
Let's switch to stestr as other projects have already moved to it.

[1] https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/YVR-python-pti

Change-Id: I09aa6a330e988070ad5b3a20b56b1c301386d657

commit_message:
Switch to use stestr

This switches to use stestr instead of testrepository, and added
openstack--cover-jobs to .zuul.yaml to separate the normal unit test
task.

Change-Id: I633acb0d6e38fa6f4d9c360d5a8eb6f7859a3ae1

commit_message:
Move doc requirements to doc/requirements.txt

Put these in place as a setup for the new versions of the doc build
jobs. Keep using them from the normal dep list until the jobs are
changed.

While we're here, update the docs env to use sphinx-build instead of
python setup.py build_sphinx. Also add python2.7 to the docs env, since
I accidentally tried building it with my python3 tox and it blew up
substantially.

Conflicts:
	setup.cfg

Modifications:
	cliff/app.py

NOTE(stephenfin): Conflicts are due to us backporting this patch before
I0f94a431be083b8b4baec850b1885ba07b5bf5c2. We're doing this since this
patch basically overrides what I0f94a431be083b8b4baec850b1885ba07b5bf5c2
did. Note that we also exclude '[venv] deps' since we don't need docs
dependencies in this anymore. The modifications are to appease flake8,
which is unpinned here.

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/658121
Change-Id: I0fcc50c4c396758e839c329ce786a6f609bb1342
(cherry picked from commit 2f687e3373a471cbf66903af736f13b58eb4ee82)

This repo is now testing only with Python 3, so let's make
a few cleanups:
- Remove python 2.7 stanza from setup.py
- Add requires on python >= 3.6 to setup.cfg so that pypi and pip
  know about the requirement
- Remove obsolete sections from setup.cfg
- Update classifiers
- Remove install_command from tox.ini, the default is fine
- Use TOX_CONSTRAINTS_FILE instead of obsolete UPPER_CONSTRAINTS_FILE.

Change-Id: I4807e406cf6238767ceb02590c713f738686fa1f
"}]
commit_message:
Cleanup py27 support

This repo is now testing only with Python 3, so let's make
a few cleanups:
- Remove python 2.7 stanza from setup.py
- Add requires on python >= 3.6 to setup.cfg so that pypi and pip
  know about the requirement
- Remove obsolete sections from setup.cfg
- Update classifiers
- Remove install_command from tox.ini, the default is fine
- Use TOX_CONSTRAINTS_FILE instead of obsolete UPPER_CONSTRAINTS_FILE.

Change-Id: I4807e406cf6238767ceb02590c713f738686fa1f

commit_message:
drop mock from lower-constraints

The mock third party library was needed for mock support in py2
runtimes. Since we now only support py36 and later, we don't need it
in lower-constraints.

These changes will help us to drop `mock` from openstack/requirements

Change-Id: I8adfadd54749890e83a3a3048ad70a16428857d7

[{'created': '2019-11-15 10:43:47.000000000', 'message': "Stop configuring install_command in tox and stop use pip.

Currently, we are overriding 'install_command' to use 'pip'. This is
considered poor behavior and 'python -m pip' should be used instead:

https://snarky.ca/why-you-should-use-python-m-pip/

It turns out that this is the the default value provided by tox:

https://tox.readthedocs.io/en/latest/config.html#conf-install_command

So we can remove the line and simply use the default value. Use the
right way when it's necessary.

Change-Id: I2f18df5d26847b6545af99e969ebbe04d3326e30

commit_message:
Stop configuring install_command in tox and stop use pip.

Currently, we are overriding 'install_command' to use 'pip'. This is
considered poor behavior and 'python -m pip' should be used instead:

https://snarky.ca/why-you-should-use-python-m-pip/

It turns out that this is the the default value provided by tox:

https://tox.readthedocs.io/en/latest/config.html#conf-install_command

So we can remove the line and simply use the default value. Use the
right way when it's necessary.

Depends-on: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/695022/
Change-Id: I2f18df5d26847b6545af99e969ebbe04d3326e30

commit_message:
Remove ValidateNtp

We already do this in the time configuration and it is no longer a
configurable item due to containers. Let's stop doing this in the all
nodes validation and let the time configuration handle the failure
messaging.

Change-Id: Ib0abcbd25117ecd587f4a92698746e5e256e6e8e
(cherry picked from commit ed2df1a05f7a19de798fe2a1b5e2a625b261c551)

commit_message:
Make volume mount path configurable for ContainerShareDriver

 Mount volumes to /tmp/ on host is not suitable for some environments
 wheen operatpr wants for specify such path for any reason.

Change-Id: Ibbdd755721de3727bf779852be039ea5639310bc

commit_message:
Update TOX_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/3.1

Update the URL to the upper-constraints file to point to the redirect
rule on releases.openstack.org so that anyone working on this branch
will switch to the correct upper-constraints list automatically when
the requirements repository branches.

Until the requirements repository has as stable/3.1 branch, tests will
continue to use the upper-constraints list on master.

Change-Id: Ice034bb721981d029d2e131a9053e34695376e23

commit_message:
drop mock from lower-constraints

The mock third party library was needed for mock support in py2
runtimes. Since we now only support py36 and later, we don't need it
in lower-constraints.

These changes will help us to drop `mock` from openstack/requirements

Change-Id: I01e577ce32814268381ed825fdb30c2d5a0980e9

commit_message:
Use unittest.mock instead of mock

The mock third party library was needed for mock support in py2
runtimes. Since we now only support py36 and later, we can use the
standard lib unittest.mock module instead.

Change-Id: I4c7cb63e0a816b361c2544b1be34d8a6dadeb5c0

This patch prepares the ground for using the latest OVN. OVN is split from

own run dir (/var/run/ovn), db dir (/etc/ovn/), log dir (/var/logs/ovn)

commit_message:
ovn-dbs-bundle: Prepare for supporting new OVN version with separarte run dirs

This patch prepares the ground for using the latest OVN. OVN is split from
openvswitch and it has its own code repo. After the split, OVN has its
own run dir (/var/run/ovn), db dir (/etc/ovn/), log dir (/var/logs/ovn)
and datadir - /usr/share/ovn/scripts.

With this patch, it supports running older version (2.11) or new
version (2.12) without any issues. It mounts the host directories accordingly
so that there is no impact when OVN is updated.

Change-Id: I5d778cbeb2863ec0fe649799863752e8eb16492f
Signed-off-by: Numan Siddique <nusiddiq@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Remove configs and entries for deprecated registry

Including removal of the example conf in docs.
Including glance-registry command entrypoint to eventlet.
Including rpc_controller from wsgi, changed to reject.
Not including the files devstack is depending on.

This change means that glance-registry starts and announces
that it has been removed.
This change means that when ran as wsgi app, all calls to
/rpc endpoint will be rejected.

This will allow devstack to make a graceful transition to
life without the glance registry, which was deprecated in
Newton release.

Change-Id: I7bf3284cba4c38605fb50b3c458e53f896f34086

commit_message:
Fix gate job failures and py3 compatibility

- Fix incorrect type handling of secret payload in py3
  (it should be bytes instead of str by default)
- Fix py3 compatibility of test codes
- Update expiration date so that resources are created with valid
  expiration.

Change-Id: I4935f601f87e9c49499da1034a320eee2e655b4d
(cherry picked from commit 6420da336083d936da9a4563149b08d785d70c84)

messages: [{'account_id': 10239, 'date': '2020-06-08 08:55:08.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 14826, 'date': '2020-06-08 09:17:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2\n\nMakes sense'}, {'account_id': 23851, 'date': '2020-06-09 14:18:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2020-06-08 08:55:08.000000000', 'message': 'Amend the in-band deploy steps spec

The current spec leaves a too narrow priority space for custom
in-band steps, while leaving 70 numbers after the final instance
is booted, which is arguably not help. Spread the proposed steps
evenly between 100 and 20, leaving 3 blocks with 19 priorities
each for customization.

Also rename "remove_provisioning_network" since removing the network
is not the only thing it does.

Change-Id: I9861f4a8878789e2ae68e8e69c4e5660e33f4989
'}]
commit_message:
Amend the in-band deploy steps spec

The current spec leaves a too narrow priority space for custom
in-band steps, while leaving 70 numbers after the final instance
is booted, which is arguably not help. Spread the proposed steps
evenly between 100 and 20, leaving 3 blocks with 19 priorities
each for customization.

Also rename "remove_provisioning_network" since removing the network
is not the only thing it does.

Change-Id: I9861f4a8878789e2ae68e8e69c4e5660e33f4989

commit_message:
[ussuri][goal] Drop python 2.7 support and testing

OpenStack is dropping the py2.7 support in ussuri cycle.

python-barbicanclient is ready with python 3 and ok to drop the
python 2.7 support.

Complete discussion & schedule can be found in
- http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-October/010142.html
- https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/drop-python2-support

Ussuri Communtiy-wide goal:
https://governance.openstack.org/tc/goals/selected/ussuri/drop-py27.html

Switch to openstackdocstheme 2.2.0 and reno 3.1.0 versions. Using
these versions will allow especially:
* Linking from HTML to PDF document
* Allow parallel building of documents
* Fix some rendering problems

Update Sphinx version as well.

openstackdocstheme renames some variables, so follow the renames

not needed anymore, remove them.

the link to the published document only works on docs.openstack.org
where the PDF file is placed in the top-level html directory. The
site-preview places the PDF in a pdf directory.

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/728938

commit_message:
Switch to newer openstackdocstheme and reno versions

Switch to openstackdocstheme 2.2.0 and reno 3.1.0 versions. Using
these versions will allow especially:
* Linking from HTML to PDF document
* Allow parallel building of documents
* Fix some rendering problems

Update Sphinx version as well.

openstackdocstheme renames some variables, so follow the renames
before the next release removes them. A couple of variables are also
not needed anymore, remove them.

Set openstackdocs_pdf_link to link to PDF file. Note that
the link to the published document only works on docs.openstack.org
where the PDF file is placed in the top-level html directory. The
site-preview places the PDF in a pdf directory.

Change pygments_style to 'native' since old theme version always used
'native' and the theme now respects the setting and using 'sphinx' can
lead to some strange rendering.

See also
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2020-May/014971.html

Change-Id: Iec58d8dfa90b9b3d7b67d81798b32fb2670e21d4

commit_message:
Cleanup repo

* Remove unused files babel.cfg and openstack-common.conf.
* Remove obsolete entries from setup.cfg.
* Remove six as requirement
* Switch to newer hacking version and fix all problems.
* Remove Babel requirement, update requirements for python3

Change-Id: I1fc46288e54a5b787afbd9ee31b32a0e7d28c6de

management tasks.

commit_message:
Add --trace flag for extra debug information

Allow 'openstack tripleo deploy' to be used in the tracing mode.
Currently this enables t-h-t ContainerManageStatsDebug flag to
aggregate containers management debug stats during deploy.

Other tracing addons may be controled by this flag as well.

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/734441
Change-Id: Id35a7fbfa2c2538aaa80f3b0cbb8a8b657b7ee5e
Partial-bug: #1879455
Signed-off-by: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobreli@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Option to process stats for containers managment

For standalone jobs, if stats collection is enabled, post-process the
file containing the collected stats. Controled by
standalone_tripleo_container_manage_stats (defaults to false).
Enable it on a CI job-by-case basis.

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/734078
Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/734483

Change-Id: I89da37ae832149069fa538aa6f59288a8662a4a4
Signed-off-by: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobreli@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Persist collected container management stats

when tripleo_container_manage_stats is set, also
dump the collected containers management stats into
tripleo_container_manage_log_path/containers_management_data.json

Change-Id: I8df8e7568f6a4122ff1caf9143875f24f64d781d
Related-bug: #1879455
Signed-off-by: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobreli@redhat.com>

not insisting that'd be the best method of parsing stats (json stdout callback would be much better, one can use it when debugging manually with direct ansible command), but important data and insights into containers management idempotency may be extracted with consequent runs and analyzing the log like this https://pastebin.com/0SxQW2QZ"}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2020-05-28 11:20:56.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 8.'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2020-05-28 11:30:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Workflow-1

testing it ...'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2020-05-29 08:12:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2020-05-29 08:12:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: -Workflow'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2020-05-29 08:26:17.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8:

I found this bringing insights and needfull for the better debugging experience. Here is results : https://pastebin.com/QFWPjjJ6 that I've got from my local env with an analogue of this simple ansible.log post-processor https://review.opendev.org/#/c/731578/

As you can see, StartedAt timestamp clearly separates the containers managed by previous deployments and those from the latest execution.

Also, you can see if its internal state identified ('changed', 'failed', 'broken', 'did not exit' and 'unknown') matches the real state in podman. Which is easy to access w/o looking into all the numerous sources of info listed in the commit msg.

And also you can find out that some of the containers, like init/bundle-init has no internal state identified for the most recent deployment run* . That may be a sign of a bug.

* - I've run it twice. The first ran didn't go further than the step1 and failed. The second run succeeded. This is also seen in the summary by timestamps and config_ids info.

So it's up to you folks either to accept that aggregator or decline it.
But I'd insist on having it for enabling better debug tooling for devs and users."}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2020-05-29 09:10:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Workflow-1

set_stats was much easier to implement ...'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2020-06-03 17:06:22.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 11.'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2020-06-03 17:06:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11: Workflow-1'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2020-06-04 16:13:13.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 12.'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2020-06-04 16:13:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12: Workflow-1'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2020-06-04 16:31:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12: -Workflow'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2020-06-04 17:00:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12:

OK now this seems done and working as I expected.

Here is an example stats snippet produced with https://review.opendev.org/731578. Note that it already helped to identify an issue being fixed in https://review.opendev.org/#/c/733657!

https://pastebin.com/ns851sYH (see the memcached State ends with 'changed' w/o further transitions. While the normal path corresponds to State=[\"changed\",\"toCheck\",\"OK\"])

In that snippet State=null also means the containers are either managed by pacemaker/externally. Or was deployed by the previous runs (time < 2020-06-04T16:22) and now are pending its newest managed actions - the provided snippet is a *not finished yet* deployment and is the "state snapshot" for the partial step<=3 execution results. After deployment finishes State=null containers, if not externally managed, should be probably pointing to other bugs in the state tracking system'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2020-06-05 11:07:04.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 13.'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2020-06-05 12:02:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 13: Workflow-1'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2020-06-05 13:42:30.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 14.'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2020-06-05 13:52:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 14:

here is the fixed view, now with all the known finite machine states in place: https://pastebin.com/Ju2qtbi5

For example, the entry
"2020-06-05T07:33:34.765602431Z: tripleo_step4:0 - nova_scheduler State=unknown PodmanStatus=running  always  fad493742522b7e191d0a9e4f28db109",

means that nova_scheduler is idempotent and runs unchanged from the previous deployment, and it has config hash fad493742522b7e191d0a9e4f28db109.

Entry
"2020-06-05T12:05:16.458097105Z: tripleo_step4:2 - swift_proxy State=changed,running PodmanStatus=running  always  fdceff9a37950280050b6b9fc2a79373",

means that swift proxy container is not idempotent and was considered changed for (each) deployment.

Finally,
"2020-06-05T12:11:13.11391255Z: tripleo_step5:0 - gnocchi_db_sync State=changed,toCheck,OK PodmanStatus=exited   1590500355 00e35e22beefff30f696384ea29550ef",

means that gnocchi_db_sync is changed, which is expected as we want it to run each deployment. It has deployment ID 1590500355 and config hash 
00e35e22beefff30f696384ea29550ef'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2020-06-05 14:17:35.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 15.'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2020-06-05 14:20:30.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 16: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2020-06-08 08:14:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 16:

PTAL'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2020-06-08 14:01:07.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 16:

I think it's better to have an option to have such data collected.
Disabled by defaults it hurts nothing..."}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2020-06-09 14:21:44.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2020-05-19 13:43:52.000000000', 'message': 'Aggregate stats for podman-managed containers

Use aggregating capabilities of get_stats to allow users to track
containers management configs and its known runtime states by the
end of deployment.

Ansible tracks the following data (by merging it on the per hosts
basis):

* input containers configs passed in with json files,
* collected from podman 'State' infos for the changed or failed
  containers and ones that required rc checks.

When executed with ANSIBLE_SHOW_CUSTOM_STATS=true or show_custom_stats
set in ansible.cfg, the given stats may be useful for users wishing
to debug issues or to build a visual representation for the managed
containers, like dependency and state graphs.

Stats may be consumed either directly from json callback or from the
produced ansible log/stdout, like that:

... skipped ansible outputs ...
CUSTOM STATS:
foo: { "one_stat": {  "11": {   "22": {    "33": 44   }  } }}

And for which after stripping off the host info ('foo: ') part,
json.loads() gives: {'one_stat': {'11': {'22': {'33': 44}}}}.

Change-Id: I453d6d5024fd9385ad7fe3d95e7f20b92097bb7f
Partial-bug: #1879455
Signed-off-by: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobreli@redhat.com>
'}, {'created': '2020-05-19 14:01:11.000000000', 'message': 'Aggregate stats for podman-managed containers

* collected from podman 'State' infos for the changed or failed
  containers and ones that required rc checks.

When executed with ANSIBLE_SHOW_CUSTOM_STATS=true or show_custom_stats
set in ansible.cfg, the given stats may be useful for users wishing
to debug issues or to build a visual representation for the managed
containers, like dependency and state graphs.

Stats may be consumed either directly from json callback or from the
produced ansible log/stdout, like that:

... skipped ansible outputs ...
CUSTOM STATS:
foo: { "one_stat": {  "11": {   "22": {    "33": 44   }  } }}

And for which after stripping off the host info ('foo: ') part,
json.loads() gives: {'one_stat': {'11': {'22': {'33': 44}}}}.

Change-Id: I453d6d5024fd9385ad7fe3d95e7f20b92097bb7f
Partial-bug: #1879455
Signed-off-by: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobreli@redhat.com>
'}, {'created': '2020-05-20 11:01:31.000000000', 'message': 'Aggregate stats for podman-managed containers

Use aggregating capabilities of get_stats to allow users to track
containers management configs and its known runtime states by the
end of deployment.

Ansible tracks the following data (by merging it on the per hosts
basis):

* input containers configs passed in with json files,
* collected from podman 'State' and 'Config' infos for the changed or
  failed containers and ones that required rc checks,
* the state identified by internal logic that analyzes runtime states.

The latter is tracked in StateIdentifiedAs, that accepts values:
'changed', 'failed', 'broken', 'did not exit' and 'unknown' as the
following:

* those that idientified as changed or failed will be assigned the
  corresponding state in theirs StateIdentifiedAs;
* those that identified as required rc check will be expanded into
  either 'broken' or 'did not exit' by the rc check completion;
* those that got input configs but have had no runtime state matched,
  are likely ones that missed their expected container management
  actions and will end up having the 'unknown' state;
* the initial value for StateIdentifiedAs is unknown and is set before
  any actions are taken.

When executed with ANSIBLE_SHOW_CUSTOM_STATS=true or show_custom_stats
set in ansible.cfg, the given stats may be useful for users wishing
to debug issues or to build a visual representation for the managed
containers, like dependency and state graphs.

Stats may be consumed either directly from json callback or from the
produced ansible log/stdout, like that:

... skipped ansible outputs ...

And for which after stripping off the host info ('foo: ') part,
json.loads() gives: {'one_stat': {'11': {'22': {'33': 44}}}}.

"}, {'created': '2020-05-29 09:40:34.000000000', 'message': "Aggregate stats for podman-managed containers

Use aggregating capabilities of get_stats to allow users to track
containers management configs and its known runtime states by the
end of deployment.

This feature is controled by tripleo_container_manage_stats and
is turned off by default. It may be enabled for a particular
CI jobs or manual debugging sessions. If it shows no performance
issues in future we can turn it on by default.

Ansible tracks the following data (by merging it on the per hosts
basis):

* input containers configs passed in with json files,
* collected from podman 'State' and 'Config' infos for the changed or
  failed containers and ones that required rc checks,
* the state identified by internal logic that analyzes runtime states.

The latter is tracked in StateIdentifiedAs, that accepts values:
'changed', 'failed', 'broken', 'did not exit' and 'unknown' as the
following:

* those that idientified as changed or failed will be assigned the
  corresponding state in theirs StateIdentifiedAs;
* those that identified as required rc check will be expanded into
  either 'broken' or 'did not exit' by the rc check completion;
* those that got input configs but have had no runtime state matched,
  are likely ones that missed their expected container management
  actions and will end up having the 'unknown' state;
* the initial value for StateIdentifiedAs is unknown and is set before
  any actions are taken.

When executed with ANSIBLE_SHOW_CUSTOM_STATS=true or show_custom_stats
set in ansible.cfg, the given stats may be useful for users wishing
to debug issues or to build a visual representation for the managed
containers, like dependency and state graphs.

Then the collected custom stats may be consumed either directly from
json callback or from the produced ansible log/stdout outputs.

Change-Id: I453d6d5024fd9385ad7fe3d95e7f20b92097bb7f
Partial-bug: #1879455
Signed-off-by: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobreli@redhat.com>
"}, {'created': '2020-06-03 15:04:38.000000000', 'message': "Aggregate data for podman-managed containers

Merge batched containers' config, run-time and internal state tracking
data to allow users to debug or visualize containers management
process. By the end of deployment it is stored into a cached fact
(containers_manage_data) so that it can be used externally until
expired.

Note: this technically may be as well achieved with get_stats.
Howewer, there may be issues when such stats are not or cannot be
displayed for reasons.

This feature is controled by tripleo_container_manage_stats and
is turned off by default. It may be enabled for a particular
CI jobs or manual debugging sessions. If it shows no performance
issues in future we can turn it on by default.

Ansible tracks the following data (by merging it on the per hosts
basis):

* input containers configs passed in with json files,
* collected from podman '.State' and '.Config.Labels' infos for the
  changed or failed containers and ones that required rc checks,
* the state identified by internal logic that analyzes runtime states
  such as failed or changed.

The latter is tracked in StateIdentifiedAs, that accepts values:
'changed', 'failed', 'to check', 'broken', 'did not exit' and 'unknown'
as the following:

* those that idientified as changed or failed or needs to be checked,
  will be assigned the corresponding state in theirs StateIdentifiedAs;
* those that identified as required rc check will be expanded into
  either 'broken' or 'did not exit' by the rc check completion;
* those that got input configs but have had no runtime state matched,
  are likely ones that missed their expected container management
  actions and will end up having the initial 'unknown' state;
* the initial value for StateIdentifiedAs is unknown and is set before
  any actions are taken.

That data may be useful for users wishing to debug issues or to build a
visual representation for the managed containers, like dependency and
state graphs.

Change-Id: I453d6d5024fd9385ad7fe3d95e7f20b92097bb7f
Partial-bug: #1879455
Signed-off-by: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobreli@redhat.com>
"}, {'created': '2020-06-03 17:06:22.000000000', 'message': "Aggregate data for podman-managed containers

"}, {'created': '2020-06-04 16:13:13.000000000', 'message': "Aggregate data for podman-managed containers

Merge batched containers' config, run-time and internal state tracking
data to allow users to debug or visualize containers management
process. By the end of deployment it is stored into a cached fact
(containers_manage_data) so that it can be used externally until
expired.

Note: this technically may be as well achieved with get_stats.
Howewer, there may be issues when such stats are not or cannot be
displayed for reasons.

This feature is controled by tripleo_container_manage_stats and
is turned off by default. It may be enabled for a particular
CI jobs or manual debugging sessions. If it shows no performance
issues in future we can turn it on by default.

Ansible tracks the following data (by merging it on the per hosts
basis):

* input containers configs passed in with json files,
* collected from podman '.State' and '.Config' infos for the
  changed or failed containers and ones that required rc checks,
* the state transitions identified by internal logic that analyzes
  runtime states such as failed or changed.

The latter is tracked in StateIdentifiedAs, that accepts a list of
the state transition values, such as:
'changed', 'failed', 'toCheck', 'broken', 'didNotExit', 'OK' and 'null'
as the following:

* those that idientified as failed or changed and needs to be checked,
  will be assigned the corresponding state in theirs StateIdentifiedAs;
* those that identified as required rc check will be expanded into
  either broken or did not exit, or finished OK;
* those that got input configs but have had no runtime state matched,
  nor had they been identified by the state machine checker as having
  any of the known/expected states, will end up having the 'null' state
  meaning there was no state transitions for such containers at all.

That data may be useful for users wishing to debug issues or to build a
visual representation for the managed containers, like dependency and
state graphs.

Change-Id: I453d6d5024fd9385ad7fe3d95e7f20b92097bb7f
Partial-bug: #1879455
Signed-off-by: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobreli@redhat.com>
"}, {'created': '2020-06-05 11:07:04.000000000', 'message': "Aggregate data for podman-managed containers

Merge batched containers configs, run-time and internal state tracking
data to allow users to debug or visualize containers management
process. By the end of deployment it is stored into a cached fact
(containers_manage_data) so that it can be used externally until
expired.

Also complete the list of possible and unexpected transitions of
containers tracked with the internal state machine:
* track containers to be checked for exit codes as an intermediate
  transition that must be expanded into the one of the other expeted
  end states.
* track changed containers that are expected to remain running after
  that (ones with the restart policy defined),
* track unexpected and unrecognized types of containers in the batch.

Note: this technically may be as well achieved with get_stats.
Howewer, there may be issues when such stats are not or cannot be
displayed for reasons.

This feature is controled by tripleo_container_manage_stats and
is turned off by default. It may be enabled for a particular
CI jobs or manual debugging sessions. If it shows no performance
issues in future we can turn it on by default.

Ansible tracks the following data (by merging it on the per hosts
basis):

* input containers configs passed in with json files,
* collected from podman '.State' and '.Config' infos for the
  changed or failed containers and ones that required rc checks,
* the state transitions identified by internal logic that analyzes
  runtime states such as failed or changed.

The latter is tracked in StateIdentifiedAs, that accepts a list of
the state transitions, such as:
* ('changed', 'failed', 'running') - changed is not the end state here;
* 'toCheck' - that must expand into either of:
  ('broken', 'didNotExit', 'OK') - all these are the end states;
* 'unexpected' and null.

Those state transitions are getting assigned to the intnernally tracked
containers managed in batches as the following:
* those that idientified as failed or changed and running, considered
  reached its end state and will get the corresponding state markers;
* those that changed but need further checking, will be added an
  intermediate toCheck state transition;
* those that identified as required rc check will be expanded into
  either broken, did not exit or finished OK end states;
* those identified as belonging to the batch but found in an unexpected
  state, will have the unexpected mark;
* other ones will end up having the null state. That may be containers
  managed externally, like by pacemaker. Or having non-matching config
  IDs. Or whatever reason that made them not identified by the state
  machine checker. That state also means that there was no state
  transitions for such containers at all.

Example in-directly unexpected state transitions that might point to
issues or bugs:
* toCheck is in the end of the transition,
* running or failed is followed by any other state transition.

That data may be useful for users wishing to debug issues or to build a
visual representation for the managed containers, like dependency and
state graphs.

Change-Id: I453d6d5024fd9385ad7fe3d95e7f20b92097bb7f
Partial-bug: #1879455
Signed-off-by: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobreli@redhat.com>
"}, {'created': '2020-06-05 13:42:30.000000000', 'message': "Aggregate data for podman-managed containers

* track containers to be checked for exit codes as an intermediate
  transition that must be expanded into the one of the other expeted

* track changed containers that are expected to remain running after
  that (ones with the restart policy defined),
* track unknown and unrecognized types of containers, like those that
  was not changed this time and remain running from the previous
  deployments; or that have unrecognized state this time because of a
  bug perhaps.

Note: this technically may be as well achieved with get_stats.
Howewer, there may be issues when such stats are not or cannot be
displayed for reasons.

This feature is controled by tripleo_container_manage_stats and
is turned off by default. It may be enabled for a particular
CI jobs or manual debugging sessions. If it shows no performance
issues in future we can turn it on by default.

Ansible tracks the following data (by merging it on the per hosts
basis):

* input containers configs passed in with json files,
* collected from podman '.State' and '.Config' infos for the
  changed or failed containers and ones that required rc checks,
* the state transitions identified by internal logic that analyzes
  runtime states such as failed or changed.

The latter is tracked in StateIdentifiedAs, that accepts a list of
the state transitions, such as:
* ('changed', 'failed', 'running') - changed is not the end state here;
* 'toCheck' - that must expand into either of:
  ('broken', 'didNotExit', 'OK') - all these are the end states;
* 'unknown/unchanged' and null.

Those state transitions are getting assigned to the intnernally tracked
containers managed in batches as the following:
* those that idientified as failed or changed and running, considered
  reached its end state and will get the corresponding state markers;
* those that changed but need further checking, will be added an
  intermediate toCheck state transition;
* those that identified as required rc check will be expanded into
  either broken, did not exit or finished OK end states;
* those identified as belonging to the batch but found in an unexpected
  state, will have the unknown/unchanged mark; unchanged containers
  that remain running since the previous deployment executions also
  fall into this category;
* other ones will end up having the null state. That may be containers
  managed externally, like by pacemaker. Or having non-matching config
  IDs. Or whatever reason that made them not identified by the state
  machine checker. That state also means that there was no state
  transitions for such containers at all.

Example in-directly unexpected state transitions that might point to
issues or bugs:
* toCheck is in the end of the transition,
* running or failed is followed by any other state transition.

That data may be useful for users wishing to debug issues or to build a
visual representation for the managed containers, like dependency and
state graphs.

Change-Id: I453d6d5024fd9385ad7fe3d95e7f20b92097bb7f

"}, {'created': '2020-06-05 14:17:35.000000000', 'message': "Aggregate data for podman-managed containers

Merge batched containers configs, run-time and internal state tracking
data to allow users to debug or visualize containers management
process. By the end of deployment it is stored into a cached fact
(containers_manage_data) so that it can be used externally until
expired.

Also complete the list of possible and unexpected transitions of
containers tracked with the internal state machine:
* track containers to be checked for exit codes as an intermediate
  transition that must be expanded into the one of the other expeted
  end states.
* also track to-be-checked containers exited normally (exit code is in
  tripleo_container_manage_valid_exit_code)
* track changed containers that are expected to remain running after
  that (ones with the restart policy defined),
* track unknown and unrecognized types of containers, like those that
  was not changed this time and remain running from the previous
  deployments; or that have unrecognized state this time because of a
  bug perhaps.

Note: this technically may be as well achieved with get_stats.
Howewer, there may be issues when such stats are not or cannot be
displayed for reasons.

This feature is controled by tripleo_container_manage_stats and
is turned off by default. It may be enabled for a particular
CI jobs or manual debugging sessions. If it shows no performance
issues in future we can turn it on by default.

Ansible tracks the following data (by merging it on the per hosts
basis):

* input containers configs passed in with json files,
* collected from podman '.State' and '.Config' infos for the
  changed or failed containers and ones that required rc checks,
* the state transitions identified by internal logic that analyzes
  runtime states such as failed or changed.

The latter is tracked in StateIdentifiedAs, that accepts a list of
the state transitions, such as:
* ('failed', 'running') - the end state with no further transitions;
* 'changed' - intermediate state, always needs to be checked for
  results;
* 'toCheck' - can only follow 'changed' and must be expanded into
  either of ('broken', 'didNotExit', 'OK') end states;
* 'unknown' and null - indicates containers not involved in any
  transitions.

Those state transitions are getting assigned to the intnernally tracked
containers managed in batches as the following:
* those that idientified as failed or changed and running, considered
  reached its end state and will get the corresponding state markers;
* those that changed but need further checking, will be added an
  intermediate toCheck state transition;
* those that identified as required rc check will be expanded into
  either broken, did not exit or finished OK end states;
* those identified as belonging to the batch but found in an unexpected
  state, will have the unknown mark (see the StartedAt timestamps);
* unchanged containers that remain running since the previous
  deployment executions also fall into 'unknown' category (howewer,
  those will have timestamp from before the deployment started);
* other ones will end up having the null state. That may be containers
  managed externally, like by pacemaker. Or having non-matching config
  IDs. Or whatever reason that made them not identified by the state
  machine checker. That state also means that there was no state
  transitions for such containers at all.

Example in-directly unexpected state transitions that might point to
issues or bugs:
* changed or toCheck is in the end of the transition for a container,
* running, failed, or any other end state is followed by another
  state transition,

That data may be useful for users wishing to debug issues or to build a
visual representation for the managed containers, like dependency and
state graphs.

Change-Id: I453d6d5024fd9385ad7fe3d95e7f20b92097bb7f
Partial-bug: #1879455
Signed-off-by: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobreli@redhat.com>

This feature is controled by tripleo_container_manage_stats and
is turned off by default. It may be enabled for a particular
CI jobs or manual debugging sessions. If it shows no performance
issues in future we can turn it on by default.

Ansible tracks the following data (by merging it on the per hosts
basis):

* input containers configs passed in with json files,
* collected from podman '.State' and '.Config' infos for the
  changed or failed containers and ones that required rc checks,
* the state transitions identified by internal logic that analyzes
  runtime states such as failed or changed.

The latter is tracked in StateIdentifiedAs, that accepts a list of
the state transitions, such as:
* ('failed', 'running') - the end state with no further transitions,
  running means 'running after changed';
* 'changed' - intermediate state, always needs to be checked for
  results or marked as 'running' otherwise;
* 'toCheck' - can only follow 'changed' and must be expanded into
  either of ('broken', 'didNotExit', 'OK') end states;
* 'unknown' and null - indicates containers not involved in any
  transitions.

Those state transitions are getting assigned to the intnernally tracked
containers managed in batches as the following:
* those that idientified as failed or changed and running, considered
  reached its end state and will get the corresponding state markers;
* those that changed but need further checking, will be added an
  intermediate toCheck state transition;
* those that identified as required rc check will be expanded into
  either broken, did not exit or finished OK end states;
* those identified as belonging to the batch but found in an unexpected
  state, will have the unknown mark (see the StartedAt timestamps);
* unchanged containers that remain running since the previous
  deployment executions also fall into 'unknown' category (howewer,
  those will have timestamp from before the deployment started);
* other ones will end up having the null state. That may be containers
  managed externally, like by pacemaker. Or having non-matching config
  IDs. Or whatever reason that made them not identified by the state
  machine checker. That state also means that there was no state
  transitions for such containers at all.

Example in-directly unexpected state transitions that might point to
issues or bugs:
* changed or toCheck is in the end of the transition for a container,
* running, failed, or any other end state is followed by another
  state transition,

That data may be useful for users wishing to debug issues or to build a
visual representation for the managed containers, like dependency and
state graphs.

Change-Id: I453d6d5024fd9385ad7fe3d95e7f20b92097bb7f
Partial-bug: #1879455
Signed-off-by: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobreli@redhat.com>
"}]
commit_message:
Aggregate data for podman-managed containers

Merge batched containers configs, run-time and internal state tracking
data to allow users to debug or visualize containers management
process. By the end of deployment it is stored into a cached fact
(containers_manage_data) so that it can be used externally until
expired.

Also complete the list of possible and unexpected transitions of
containers tracked with the internal state machine:
* track containers to be checked for exit codes as an intermediate
  transition that must be expanded into the one of the other expeted
  end states.
* also track to-be-checked containers exited normally (exit code is in
  tripleo_container_manage_valid_exit_code)
* track changed containers that are expected to remain running after
  that (ones with the restart policy defined),
* track unknown and unrecognized types of containers, like those that
  was not changed this time and remain running from the previous
  deployments; or that have unrecognized state this time because of a
  bug perhaps.

Note: this technically may be as well achieved with get_stats.
Howewer, there may be issues when such stats are not or cannot be
displayed for reasons.

This feature is controled by tripleo_container_manage_stats and
is turned off by default. It may be enabled for a particular
CI jobs or manual debugging sessions. If it shows no performance
issues in future we can turn it on by default.

Ansible tracks the following data (by merging it on the per hosts
basis):

* input containers configs passed in with json files,
* collected from podman '.State' and '.Config' infos for the
  changed or failed containers and ones that required rc checks,
* the state transitions identified by internal logic that analyzes
  runtime states such as failed or changed.

The latter is tracked in StateIdentifiedAs, that accepts a list of
the state transitions, such as:
* ('failed', 'running') - the end state with no further transitions,
  running means 'running after changed';
* 'changed' - intermediate state, always needs to be checked for
  results or marked as 'running' otherwise;
* 'toCheck' - can only follow 'changed' and must be expanded into
  either of ('broken', 'didNotExit', 'OK') end states;
* 'unknown' and null - indicates containers not involved in any
  transitions.

Those state transitions are getting assigned to the intnernally tracked
containers managed in batches as the following:
* those that idientified as failed or changed and running, considered
  reached its end state and will get the corresponding state markers;
* those that changed but need further checking, will be added an
  intermediate toCheck state transition;
* those that identified as required rc check will be expanded into
  either broken, did not exit or finished OK end states;
* those identified as belonging to the batch but found in an unexpected
  state, will have the unknown mark (see the StartedAt timestamps);
* unchanged containers that remain running since the previous
  deployment executions also fall into 'unknown' category (howewer,
  those will have timestamp from before the deployment started);
* other ones will end up having the null state. That may be containers
  managed externally, like by pacemaker. Or having non-matching config
  IDs. Or whatever reason that made them not identified by the state
  machine checker. That state also means that there was no state
  transitions for such containers at all.

Example in-directly unexpected state transitions that might point to
issues or bugs:
* changed or toCheck is in the end of the transition for a container,
* running, failed, or any other end state is followed by another
  state transition,

That data may be useful for users wishing to debug issues or to build a
visual representation for the managed containers, like dependency and
state graphs.

Change-Id: I453d6d5024fd9385ad7fe3d95e7f20b92097bb7f
Partial-bug: #1879455
Signed-off-by: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobreli@redhat.com>

subject: Switch to newer openstackdocstheme version
messages: [{'account_id': 6547, 'date': '2020-06-03 19:10:30.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 2, 'date': '2020-06-09 14:04:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2020-06-09 14:08:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2020-06-03 19:10:30.000000000', 'message': "Switch to newer openstackdocstheme version

Switch to openstackdocstheme 2.2.1 version. Using
this version will allow especially:
* Linking from HTML to PDF document
* Allow parallel building of documents
* Fix some rendering problems

Update Sphinx version as well.

Disable openstackdocs_auto_version to not auto-version the documents.

Disable openstackdocs_auto_name to use 'project' variable as name.

Change pygments_style to 'native' since old theme version always used
'native' and the theme now respects the setting and using 'sphinx' can
lead to some strange rendering.

Remove docs requirements from lower-constraints, they are not needed
during install or test but only for docs building.

openstackdocstheme renames some variables, so follow the renames
before the next release removes them. A couple of variables are also
not needed anymore, remove them.

See also
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2020-May/014971.html

Change-Id: I33db298dd24f1e9795fb789f7c6964a97ba0651f
"}]
commit_message:
Switch to newer openstackdocstheme version

Switch to openstackdocstheme 2.2.1 version. Using
this version will allow especially:
* Linking from HTML to PDF document
* Allow parallel building of documents
* Fix some rendering problems

Update Sphinx version as well.

Disable openstackdocs_auto_version to not auto-version the documents.

Disable openstackdocs_auto_name to use 'project' variable as name.

Change pygments_style to 'native' since old theme version always used
'native' and the theme now respects the setting and using 'sphinx' can
lead to some strange rendering.

Remove docs requirements from lower-constraints, they are not needed
during install or test but only for docs building.

openstackdocstheme renames some variables, so follow the renames
before the next release removes them. A couple of variables are also
not needed anymore, remove them.

See also
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2020-May/014971.html

Change-Id: I33db298dd24f1e9795fb789f7c6964a97ba0651f

commit_message:
Use unittest.mock instead of third party mock

Now that we no longer support py27, we can use the standard library
unittest.mock module instead of the third party mock lib.

Change-Id: I3b728aee2f07ad547ee75cabf78659cef1233bc5
Signed-off-by: Sean McGinnis <sean.mcginnis@gmail.com>

commit_message:
drop mock from lower-constraints and requirements

The mock third party library was needed for mock support in py2
runtimes. Since we now only support py36 and later, we don't need it
in lower-constraints and requirements.

These changes will help us to drop `mock` from openstack/requirements

Change-Id: I71a09f2eddd3a344225cb69f9679e99fdeb3e2db

commit_message:
Cleanup py27 support

This repo is now testing only with Python 3, so let's make
a few cleanups:
- Remove python 2.7 stanza from setup.py
- Remove obsolete sections from setup.cfg
- Update classifiers
- Remove Babel from requirements, it's not needed for running,
  remove babel.cfg.
- remove obsolete file openstack-common.conf.
- Use TOX_CONSTRAINTS_FILE instead of obsolete UPPER_CONSTRAINTS_FILE.
- Update hacking to current version

Change-Id: I130f1a45151dd45426b99869f40b54361278b5c7

commit_message:
drop mock from lower-constraints

The mock third party library was needed for mock support in py2
runtimes. Since we now only support py36 and later, we don't need it
in lower-constraints.

These changes will help us to drop `mock` from openstack/requirements

Change-Id: I29f0c4b67096dcf089537fa9282ec568f69da66a

commit_message:
Fix pygments style

New theme of docs (Victoria+) respects pygments_style.
Since we starts using Victoria reqs while being on Ussuri,
this patch ensures proper rendering both in Ussuri and Victoria.

Change-Id: I76b0d9531ece65835f09058f9b22cb5860826dc4

commit_message:
drop mock from lower-constraints

The mock third party library was needed for mock support in py2
runtimes. Since we now only support py36 and later, we don't need it
in lower-constraints.

These changes will help us to drop `mock` from openstack/requirements

Change-Id: I264cfc61d6f20ac0842931b793bf72935fdd550d

runtimes. Since we now only support py36 and later, we don't need it
in lower-constraints and requirements.

These changes will help us to drop `mock` from openstack/requirements

[{'created': '2020-06-01 13:58:17.000000000', 'message': "Switch to newer openstackdocstheme and reno versions

* Linking from HTML to PDF document
* Allow parallel building of documents
* Fix some rendering problems

Update Sphinx version as well.

Disable openstackdocs_auto_name to use 'project' variable as name.

Change pygments_style to 'native' since old theme version always used

not needed anymore, remove them.

commit_message:
Switch to newer openstackdocstheme and reno versions

Switch to openstackdocstheme 2.2.1 and reno 3.1.0 versions. Using
these versions will allow especially:
* Linking from HTML to PDF document
* Allow parallel building of documents
* Fix some rendering problems

Update Sphinx version as well.

Disable openstackdocs_auto_name to use 'project' variable as name.

Change pygments_style to 'native' since old theme version always used
'native' and the theme now respects the setting and using 'sphinx' can
lead to some strange rendering.

openstackdocstheme renames some variables, so follow the renames
before the next release removes them. A couple of variables are also
not needed anymore, remove them.

See also
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2020-May/014971.html

Change-Id: I626737549ce3aeff0eeef63c42e6330d70192a63

commit_message:
Use unittest.mock instead of mock

The mock third party library was needed for mock support in py2
runtimes. Since we now only support py36 and later, we can use the
standard lib unittest.mock module instead.

Change-Id: I837241a34505496a3a152d72f28f23687ded1088

drop mock from lower-constraints

The mock third party library was needed for mock support in py2
runtimes. Since we now only support py36 and later, we don't need it
in lower-constraints.

These changes will help us to drop `mock` from openstack/requirements

Change-Id: I46b98c7a61f2e19b68eee521c9c71971b0df9ad8

subject: [hca] Join threads before closing file descriptor
messages:
[{'account_id': 28022, 'date': '2020-05-15 07:06:40.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 28022, 'date': '2020-05-15 07:11:02.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 20498, 'date': '2020-05-15 08:33:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

If I was running a script or a process with systemd (like we do for openstack services using CentOS/RDO) the expected thing to do is to get stderr in journal (i.e. journalctl -f <service>) and the logs of the service in a log file. This behaviour is configured at the service level (e.g. openstack-nova-compute.service)

In our case, the logs of the service (the service is the script) are both stdout and stderr. I think it is better to execute the process and let the process send the logs where we want. Since the service is a bash script we do it natively piping the logs to a single file.

So:
execute the script and pipe stdout and stderr to a single file. IMO we can avoid logging both in the heat-agent log and in a file. We can log only in a file. having stderr empty in the software deployment object is ok, if we decide to do 2>&1 (using python or not).

What do you think?

I think less is more!'}, {'account_id': 28022, 'date': '2020-05-15 09:39:50.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

> If I was running a script or a process with systemd (like we do for
 > openstack services using CentOS/RDO) the expected thing to do is to
 > get stderr in journal (i.e. journalctl -f <service>) and the logs
 > of the service in a log file. This behaviour is configured at the
 > service level (e.g. openstack-nova-compute.service)
 > 
 > In our case, the logs of the service (the service is the script)
 > are both stdout and stderr. I think it is better to execute the
 > process and let the process send the logs where we want. Since the
 > service is a bash script we do it natively piping the logs to a
 > single file.
 > 
 > So:
 > execute the script and pipe stdout and stderr to a single file. IMO
 > we can avoid logging both in the heat-agent log and in a file. We
 > can log only in a file. having stderr empty in the software
 > deployment object is ok, if we decide to do 2>&1 (using python or
 > not).
 > 
 > What do you think?
 > 
 > I think less is more!

I find the stdout summary useful as a way of tracking how far the cluster creation has progressed and it would be a shame to lose that as there is usually a lot of noise when the stdout+stderr output is combined. Also this approach allows us to ensure that the outputs software deployment is rendered correctly.

If this does not fix Feilong's issue, I will resign to a 2&>1 (I have tested this before and it appears to work but just doesn't provide the separation of stdout and stderr which I care about) approach as I wouldn't like to have broken code upstream."}, {'account_id': 20498, 'date': '2020-05-15 09:58:57.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

> > If I was running a script or a process with systemd (like we do
 > for
 > > openstack services using CentOS/RDO) the expected thing to do is
 > to
 > > get stderr in journal (i.e. journalctl -f <service>) and the logs
 > > of the service in a log file. This behaviour is configured at the
 > > service level (e.g. openstack-nova-compute.service)
 > >
 > > In our case, the logs of the service (the service is the script)
 > > are both stdout and stderr. I think it is better to execute the
 > > process and let the process send the logs where we want. Since
 > the
 > > service is a bash script we do it natively piping the logs to a
 > > single file.
 > >
 > > So:
 > > execute the script and pipe stdout and stderr to a single file.
 > IMO
 > > we can avoid logging both in the heat-agent log and in a file. We
 > > can log only in a file. having stderr empty in the software
 > > deployment object is ok, if we decide to do 2>&1 (using python or
 > > not).
 > >
 > > What do you think?
 > >
 > > I think less is more!
 > 
 > I find the stdout summary useful as a way of tracking how far the
 > cluster creation has progressed and it would be a shame to lose
 > that as there is usually a lot of noise when the stdout+stderr
 > output is combined. Also this approach allows us to ensure that the
 > outputs software deployment is rendered correctly.
 > 
 > If this does not fix Feilong's issue, I will resign to a 2&>1 (I
 > have tested this before and it appears to work but just doesn't
 > provide the separation of stdout and stderr which I care about)
 > approach as I wouldn't like to have broken code upstream.

Broken code is an aggressive statement for using 2&>1.

If you want to do the right thing and have stderr,stdout working separately
properly and give the option for following live the log in the node, we can
go back to the separate file logic. One for stdout and one for stderr.
We can have as a goal to have only meaningful messages printed and catch
errors."}, {'account_id': 28022, 'date': '2020-05-15 10:02:39.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

> > > If I was running a script or a process with systemd (like we do
 > > for
 > > > openstack services using CentOS/RDO) the expected thing to do
 > is
 > > to
 > > > get stderr in journal (i.e. journalctl -f <service>) and the
 > logs
 > > > of the service in a log file. This behaviour is configured at
 > the
 > > > service level (e.g. openstack-nova-compute.service)
 > > >
 > > > In our case, the logs of the service (the service is the
 > script)
 > > > are both stdout and stderr. I think it is better to execute the
 > > > process and let the process send the logs where we want. Since
 > > the
 > > > service is a bash script we do it natively piping the logs to a
 > > > single file.
 > > >
 > > > So:
 > > > execute the script and pipe stdout and stderr to a single file.
 > > IMO
 > > > we can avoid logging both in the heat-agent log and in a file.
 > We
 > > > can log only in a file. having stderr empty in the software
 > > > deployment object is ok, if we decide to do 2>&1 (using python
 > or
 > > > not).
 > > >
 > > > What do you think?
 > > >
 > > > I think less is more!
 > >
 > > I find the stdout summary useful as a way of tracking how far the
 > > cluster creation has progressed and it would be a shame to lose
 > > that as there is usually a lot of noise when the stdout+stderr
 > > output is combined. Also this approach allows us to ensure that
 > the
 > > outputs software deployment is rendered correctly.
 > >
 > > If this does not fix Feilong's issue, I will resign to a 2&>1 (I
 > > have tested this before and it appears to work but just doesn't
 > > provide the separation of stdout and stderr which I care about)
 > > approach as I wouldn't like to have broken code upstream.
 > 
 > Broken code is an aggressive statement for using 2&>1.
 > 
 > If you want to do the right thing and have stderr,stdout working
 > separately
 > properly and give the option for following live the log in the
 > node, we can
 > go back to the separate file logic. One for stdout and one for
 > stderr.
 > We can have as a goal to have only meaningful messages printed and
 > catch
 > errors.

i.e. broken code (especially one that I introduced) upstream. Wasn't meant in at all agressive way."}, {'account_id': 28022, 'date': '2020-05-19 08:51:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Are you having any more issues with HCA @flwang?'}, {'account_id': 20498, 'date': '2020-05-19 08:54:03.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

So we do threads? Feilong, have you updated the image in your production environment?

I'm  scared to do it? (As it always happens with ops, when the admin tries it works.)"}, {'account_id': 28022, 'date': '2020-05-20 10:15:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

@flwang do you have any feedback for this?'}, {'account_id': 20498, 'date': '2020-05-20 10:43:49.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

I'm not against the design by any means.

Due to due to lack of testing infrastructure in our project, I feel much more confident to a design without threads. Just my 2c."}, {'account_id': 20498, 'date': '2020-05-20 10:43:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

waiting for Feilong'}, {'account_id': 20498, 'date': '2020-05-25 11:40:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

ping feilong'}, {'account_id': 20498, 'date': '2020-05-26 08:38:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

ping feilong'}, {'account_id': 6484, 'date': '2020-05-27 01:18:59.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Sorry, guys. I'm going to test it now."}, {'account_id': 6484, 'date': '2020-05-27 05:47:34.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

In my today test, I can't reproduce the thread issue with either ussuri-dev and image built from this patch. So let's hold this one a bit and I will continually keep an eye on this. Thank you for you guys work and comments."}, {'account_id': 28022, 'date': '2020-05-28 08:30:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

for reference, the heat_container_agent_tag to test this change is: 728374-0723764daf932a64c7725a044ef94e392dfc24b4'}, {'account_id': 28022, 'date': '2020-06-03 08:48:31.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 6484, 'date': '2020-06-03 08:52:22.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Code-Review+2

As I said before, I can't reproduce the issue with this one. And I agree with Bharat, we should use join thread anyway. So I'm happy to get this one in."}, {'account_id': 28022, 'date': '2020-06-03 08:53:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

While we are still evaluating which approach to take, there is no harm in merging this patch which joins threads before closing file descriptor.'}, {'account_id': 28022, 'date': '2020-06-03 08:57:46.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4: Patch Set 3 was rebased.'}, {'account_id': 20498, 'date': '2020-06-03 09:04:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1

FYI, I continue to be worried, but there is nothing we can do. :)'}, {'account_id': 28022, 'date': '2020-06-03 09:06:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

@Spyros, not sure if this is reassuring but we have been using train-stable-2 tag for around 3 months in various sites and it has been reasonably stable despite the multi-threading :)'}, {'account_id': 20498, 'date': '2020-06-03 09:12:16.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

> @Spyros, not sure if this is reassuring but we have been using
 > train-stable-2 tag for around 3 months in various sites and it has
 > been reasonably stable despite the multi-threading :)

The reasoning is:
* This WAY MORE complicated than piping both logs to stdout or logging in differnt files. Please note that I compare it to a much simpler solution, not saying that is in general a complicated design.
* We don't have tests. This is a problem in general not with this patch. But lack of testing is more prevalent with cases like this.

It would be great if you could share the number of nodes you booted with train-stable-2 and the fedora coreos/atomic version."}, {'account_id': 20498, 'date': '2020-06-09 10:38:33.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

We broke production with train-stable-2

It clearly doesn't work. I didn't see it in devstack. But un production the same IOError appeared. I don't know why or under which conditions train-stable-2 works."}, {'account_id': 28022, 'date': '2020-06-09 10:50:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

Are you seeing the same with train-stable-3?'}, {'account_id': 28022, 'date': '2020-06-09 10:56:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

Can you please paste the error in storyboard?'}, {'account_id': 20498, 'date': '2020-06-09 13:02:51.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

> Are you seeing the same with train-stable-3?

don't know yet"}, {'account_id': 20498, 'date': '2020-06-09 13:03:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

> Can you please paste the error in storyboard?

this is the error https://storyboard.openstack.org/#!/story/2007264#comment-158316

You posted it already'}]

commit_message:
[hca] Join threads before closing file descriptor

In some environments, heat container agent is erroring because of file
descriptor closing before threads have joined.

Change-Id: I1de5042ea5f4229518e96b985b1832dcacb052db
Story: 2007264
Task: 39788

commit_message:
Remove empty default LVM configuration

Since this configuration uses the overlay storage driver, it doesn't
require the LVM data volume group, previously we set the list of VGs to
empty.

Kayobe in Ussuri is modifying the default configuration such that the
VG list will be empty by default unless using the devicemapper driver.

This change removes the VG configuration override.

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/722316

Change-Id: I0ebe05baa67ea71b3df77f2e7f7870a237e4cb23
Story: 2005667
Task: 39537

commit_message:
Configure ansible forks based on cores

At present we use a fixed value of 36. It seems the emperical
formula is 4 forks per core ans would be automatically limited
by ansible to the number of hosts.

Change-Id: I9a9e600935e3b8443341a1dc28421a19d9978bfe
(cherry picked from commit ce948ae04947596afe2e1acefaca0a7813f1268f)

commit_message:
Fix bifrost_inventory.py with no nodes enrolled

Run the bifrost_inventory.py script withBIFROST_INVENTORY_SOURCE=ironic,
and no hosts enrolled in ironic. It fails:

    RuntimeError: dictionary changed size during iteration

This change fixes the issue by using a copy of the groups dictionary.

Change-Id: I614580c37406a75eab356fdc217a3ffa052bc5ff
Story: 2007776
Task: 40002
(cherry picked from commit 3ffa9c78376f75acc418590489125a8ba0769ab0)

commit_message:
New extension call to return partition UUIDs

Currently we parse the success message from the write_image call.
This is inconvenient and incompatible with the deploy steps split.

Change-Id: I258dc1ff1ad1c9df5cbc26a7825d9e7ef2f3205b
Story: #2006963

[{'created': '2020-06-06 10:11:43.000000000', 'message': 'devstack: increase concurrency and worker timeout for sushy-tools

Sometimes sushy-tools hits worker timeout in gunicorn when handing
a virtual media ISO, causing a request to be aborted and deployment
to fail. Increase the timeout from 30 to 90 seconds and add some
concurrency to ensure that more than one deployment can run.

Change-Id: I9e951aaaa13981602151bff3f2eebfa338113f6c
'}]
commit_message:
devstack: increase concurrency and worker timeout for sushy-tools

Sometimes sushy-tools hits worker timeout in gunicorn when handing
a virtual media ISO, causing a request to be aborted and deployment
to fail. Increase the timeout from 30 to 90 seconds and add some
concurrency to ensure that more than one deployment can run.

Change-Id: I9e951aaaa13981602151bff3f2eebfa338113f6c

commit_message:
drop mock from lower-constraints

The mock third party library was needed for mock support in py2
runtimes. Since we now only support py36 and later, we don't need it
in lower-constraints.

These changes will help us to drop `mock` from openstack/requirements

Change-Id: I16298d48f6be9d994c13f0e5c400768d9445cbb0

commit_message:
Make the install_bootloader command asynchronous

It does not return anything, so it makes no point for it to be
synchronous. Ironic always calls it with wait=True, so there is
no problem with backward compatibility either.

Change-Id: I44fec2e0cb54486328ce71263613d8592e384870

Your submission will now be tested automatically by Zuul, our gatekeeper,

People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be

Patches often take days (and sometimes weeks) to get reviewed, so be

fastest way to accomplish this is by reviewing other proposed changes

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-05-29 15:14:24.000000000', 'message': "Fix test_barbican_legacy for Python 3.8

Fixes failing unit tests in
octavia.tests.unit.certificates.manager.test_barbican_legacy.TestBarbicanManager
for Python 3.8

Some of the tests fail setting up a mock.Mock(spec=secrets.Secret)
because a ValueError exception is raised unexpectedly.

The reason is that test_get_cert_no_registration_raise_on_secret_access_failure
patches the `payload` property of barbicanclient.v1.secrets.Secret to
raise a ValueError.
When a subsequent test tries to set up a mock.Mock(spec=secrets.Secret)
in Python 3.8 the Mock class will try to look at the properties of the spec
class and accessing `payload` doesn't behave normally anymore: it raises
ValueError now.

Fixed by using a different approach of mocking `payload` in
test_get_cert_no_registration_raise_on_secret_access_failure
so that it does not influence subsequent tests.

Change-Id: Ic534a4715c85c2216c7251209507acf74a999153
Story: 2007490
Task: 39212
"}]
commit_message:
Fix test_barbican_legacy for Python 3.8

Fixes failing unit tests in
octavia.tests.unit.certificates.manager.test_barbican_legacy.TestBarbicanManager
for Python 3.8

Some of the tests fail setting up a mock.Mock(spec=secrets.Secret)
because a ValueError exception is raised unexpectedly.

The reason is that test_get_cert_no_registration_raise_on_secret_access_failure
patches the `payload` property of barbicanclient.v1.secrets.Secret to
raise a ValueError.
When a subsequent test tries to set up a mock.Mock(spec=secrets.Secret)
in Python 3.8 the Mock class will try to look at the properties of the spec
class and accessing `payload` doesn't behave normally anymore: it raises
ValueError now.

Fixed by using a different approach of mocking `payload` in
test_get_cert_no_registration_raise_on_secret_access_failure
so that it does not influence subsequent tests.

Change-Id: Ic534a4715c85c2216c7251209507acf74a999153
Story: 2007490

commit_message:
drop mock from lower-constraints

The mock third party library was needed for mock support in py2
runtimes. Since we now only support py36 and later, we don't need it
in lower-constraints.

These changes will help us to drop `mock` from openstack/requirements

Change-Id: I52c45e07c20de8f8abe439675e5fa5256d0d375e

subject: Add dynamic-portgroups spec for NGS
messages:
[{'account_id': 25943, 'date': '2018-04-13 07:10:00.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 27369, 'date': '2018-04-16 08:31:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 14826, 'date': '2018-04-16 13:54:46.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Thanks for uploading this spec Zachary. It's not quite what I had in mind - it's an almost word for word copy of the related Dynamic Port Groups [1] ironic spec. We're not reimplementing that feature, so a lot of the information is redundant.

What I'd like to see is:

* Problem description: what is the problem we're trying to solve?
* Include use case(s). At the very least, a description of your specific use case. What topologies and bonding modes will be supported? Single switch and/or multi-chassis?
* Proposed solution: what will the solution look like? What needs to change? which parts are general vs. which parts are specific to the Huawei drivers? Which properties from the local group information will be used? Do the huawei drivers require any custom properties?

Gaetan, please also ensure that your use case is covered here.

[1] https://specs.openstack.org/openstack/ironic-specs/specs/not-implemented/dynamic-portgroups.html"}, {'account_id': 14826, 'date': '2018-04-16 13:54:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1'}, {'account_id': 24828, 'date': '2018-04-17 00:39:37.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

(2 comments)

Agreed with Mark. Perhaps we should avoid using dynamic-portgroup in the title, it's a work previously done.

The portgroup information is passed to ml2 driver in the local_group_information of binding profile, while currently ngs only handles vlan configuration. I believe what we'll do is in what way we apply these configuration to the switch, and cover most use cases."}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-04-13 07:10:00.000000000', 'message': 'Add dynamic-portgroups spec for NGS

Change-Id: I3a60512383c24fb54aeba354c991e5decf479d15
'}]

Add dynamic-portgroups spec for NGS

Change-Id: I3a60512383c24fb54aeba354c991e5decf479d15

runtimes. Since we now only support py36 and later, we don't need it
in lower-constraints.

commit_message:
Fix multiple issues

Both issues affect Train and earlier releases.

1. Fix monasca-grafana by pinning more Ruby gems

childprocess 3.0.0 and ffi 1.13.0 depend on Ruby 2.3.

2. Bump bifrost to 6.0.4

Bifrost had a fix to stop using the master branch of DIB which dropped
support for Python 2.

3. Drop docker-client from OracleLinux sensu-client image

The package fails to install due to a missing dependency on
subscription-manager.

Change-Id: Ida7e20833360bbca69c6aafc4f5d7cb375bb106f
Closes-Bug: #1882070
(cherry picked from commit 3784d32d9ceacf0dad8057092752f1ae7be37ed3)

commit_message:
drop mock from lower-constraints

The mock third party library was needed for mock support in py2
runtimes. Since we now only support py36 and later, we don't need it
in lower-constraints.

These changes will help us to drop `mock` from openstack/requirements

Change-Id: I8a601ad5af5ba2e9290c3f36a44d94d1dc9d3e20

removal of controllers.

commit_message:
Fix bifrost_inventory.py with no nodes enrolled

Run the bifrost_inventory.py script withBIFROST_INVENTORY_SOURCE=ironic,
and no hosts enrolled in ironic. It fails:

    RuntimeError: dictionary changed size during iteration

This change fixes the issue by using a copy of the groups dictionary.

Change-Id: I614580c37406a75eab356fdc217a3ffa052bc5ff
Story: 2007776
Task: 40002

openstack/requirements repo) are dropped from lower-constraints.txt

commit_message:
Remove the unused coding style modules

Python modules related to coding style checks (listed in blacklist.txt in
openstack/requirements repo) are dropped from lower-constraints.txt
as they are not actually used in tests (other than pep8).

more info: https://github.com/openstack/requirements/blob/master/blacklist.txt

Change-Id: Icbdc9e3e501f3c8a2971b91ccb61642754d9457e
